name: client-http

jsDoc.doc:
HTTP response union type representing all possible response states.

- **Success (2xx)**: `processed: true, ok: true, error: null`
- **Error (4xx/5xx)**: `processed: true, ok: false, error: HttpError`
- **Failure (network error)**: `processed: false, ok: false, error: Error`

HTTP response for error responses (4xx/5xx status codes).

Server received and processed the request, but returned an error status.

HTTP response for request failures (network errors, timeouts, etc.).

Request could not be processed by the server (network error, DNS failure,
connection refused, timeout, aborted, etc.).
No raw response (request didn't reach server).
Server did not process the request.
Error describing the failure (ConnectionError, TimeoutError, AbortError).
No HTTP status (request didn't reach server).
No HTTP status text (request didn't reach server).

HTTP response for successful requests (2xx status codes).

Wraps Web standard Response, allowing body to be read synchronously
and multiple times (unlike the streaming-based standard Response).

Redirect handling mode.
- "follow": Automatically follow redirects (default)
- "manual": Return redirect response without following
- "error": Throw error on redirect
Query parameters type - accepts URLSearchParams or plain object.

tags.value: @default "follow" (inherited from client config if not specified)

jsDoc.doc:
Whether to throw HttpError for non-2xx responses.
When false, non-2xx responses are returned as HttpResponse.

tags.value: @default false (inherited from client config if not specified)

jsDoc.doc: Options for HTTP requests that may include a body.

Disable automatic cookie handling.
When disabled, cookies are not stored or sent automatically.
Initial cookies to populate the cookie jar.

HTTP connection configuration.

Extends CommonConnectionConfig with HTTP-specific options.
Base path prefix for all requests.

Base URL for all requests.

Can be a URL string or a connection configuration object.

Default redirect handling mode.
Can be overridden per-request via HttpOptions.

Whether to throw HttpError for non-2xx responses.
Can be overridden per-request via HttpOptions.

Cookie handling configuration.
By default, the client maintains a cookie jar for automatic
cookie management across requests.
Set `cookies: { disabled: true }` to disable.

Get all cookies in the cookie jar.
Returns empty object if cookies are disabled.
Set a cookie in the cookie jar.

Clear all cookies from the cookie jar.
No-op if cookies are disabled.
Close the client and release resources

HTTP error class for non-2xx responses.

This error is thrown (or returned in response.error) when the server
responds with a 4xx or 5xx status code. It includes the response body
for inspecting error details.
Response body as raw bytes (null if no body)
Get body as ArrayBuffer (null if no body)
Get body as Blob (null if no body)
Get body as text (null if no body)
Get body as parsed JSON (null if no body).

tags.name: T
tags.doc: - defaults to any for test convenience
SyntaxError if body is not valid JSON

jsDoc.doc:
Error thrown when a network-level failure occurs.

This error indicates that the request could not be processed by the server
due to network issues (connection refused, DNS resolution failure, etc.).

Error types that indicate the operation was not processed.
These are errors that occur before the request reaches the server.

Create a new HTTP client instance.

The client provides methods for making HTTP requests with automatic
cookie handling, response body pre-loading, and error handling.

tags.name: config
tags.doc: - Client configuration including URL and default options

jsDoc.doc:
Implementation of HttpResponseError.
Proxies body methods to the HttpError instance.
